simulatable.orig_qn:
A 22-year-old male marathon runner presents to the office with the complaint of right-sided rib pain when he runs long distances. Physical examination reveals normal heart and lung findings and an exhalation dysfunction at ribs 4-5 on the right. Which of the following muscles or muscle groups will be most useful in correcting this dysfunction utilizing a direct method?
A. anterior scalene
B. latissimus dorsi
C. pectoralis minor
D. quadratus lumborum
simulatable.orig_qa_tm_expl: Among the options, only latissimus dorsi muscle origins from the outer surfaces of the 3rd to 5th ribs.
simulatable.sim_qn:
A 19-year-old female ballet dancer presents to the office with the complaint of sharp shoulder pain and limited range of motion during overhead movements. Physical examination reveals normal heart and lung findings and an inhalation dysfunction at ribs 3-5 on the left. Which of the following muscles or muscle groups will be most useful in correcting this dysfunction utilizing a direct method? 
A. anterior scalene
B. quadratus lumborum
C. pectoralis minor
D. latissimus dorsi
simulatable.sim_qa_expl: We know from the starter QA that latissimus dorsi muscle origins from the outer surfaces of the 3rd to 5th ribs. Since the patient in the follow-up question also suffers from inhalation dysfunction at ribs 3-5 on the left, we know that the 19-year-old also needs treatment for her latissimus dorsi. So the answer is D.
simulatable.relevant_qa_expl: Latissimus dorsi muscle origins from the outer surfaces of the 3rd to 5th ribs. So the answer is D.

simulatable.orig_qn:
A 36-year-old male presents to the office with a 3-week history of low back pain. He denies any recent trauma but says that he climbs in and out of his truck numerous times a day for his job. Examination of the patient in the prone position reveals a deep sacral sulcus on the left, a posterior inferior lateral angle on the right, and a lumbosacral junction that springs freely on compression. The most likely diagnosis is
A. left-on-left sacral torsion
B. left-on-right sacral torsion 
C. right unilateral sacral flexion
D. right-on-right sacral torsion
simulatable.orig_qa_tm_expl: The deep sulcus on the left, a posterior ILA on the right, with a negative spring test suggests a right-on-right sacral torsion. All other options have a deep sulcus on the right.
simulatable.sim_qn:
A 42-year-old female presents to the office with a 4-week history of left-sided hip pain. She reports no recent injuries but mentions that she plays tennis regularly and often performs powerful right-handed swings. Examination of the patient in a supine position reveals a deep sulcus on the left, a posterior inferior lateral angle on the right, and a hip joint that springs freely on compression. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
A. right-on-right sacral torsion
B. left-on-left sacral torsion
C. right unilateral sacral flexion
D. left-on-right sacral torsion
simulatable.sim_qa_expl: We know from the starter QA that a deep sulcus on the left, a posterior ILA on the right, with a negative spring test suggests a right-on-right sacral torsion. Since the patient in the follow-up question also exhibits these symptoms, she likely also has right-on-right sacral torsion. So the answer is A.
simulatable.relevant_qa_expl: A deep sulcus on the left, a posterior ILA on the right, with a negative spring test suggests a right-on-right sacral torsion. So the answer is A.

simulatable.orig_qn:
A 44-year-old man comes to the office because of a 3-day history of sore throat, nonproductive cough, runny nose, and frontal headache. He says the headache is worse in the morning and ibuprofen does provide some relief. He has not had shortness of breath. Medical history is unremarkable. He takes no medications other than the ibuprofen for pain. Vital signs are temperature 37.4째C (99.4째F), pulse 88/min, respirations 18/min, and blood pressure 120/84 mm Hg. Examination of the nares shows erythematous mucous membranes. Examination of the throat shows erythema and follicular lymphoid hyperplasia on the posterior oropharynx. There is no palpable cervical adenopathy. Lungs are clear to auscultation. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?
A. Rhinovirus
B. Epstein-Barr virus
C. Mycoplasma pneumonia
D. Allergic rhinitis
simulatable.orig_qa_tm_expl: The symptoms, especially the headache, suggest that the most likely cause is Rhinovirus. Epstein-Barr virus will cause swollen lymph nodes but there is no palpable cervical adenopathy. Lungs are clear to auscultation suggests it's not Mycoplasma pneumonia.
simulatable.sim_qn:
A 25-year-old woman presents with a 5-day history of runny nose, sneezing, and sore throat. She also complains of a severe headache that worsens in the morning but is relieved with over-the-counter pain medication. On examination, her nares show erythematous mucous membranes, and her throat shows erythema and follicular lymphoid hyperplasia. There is no palpable cervical adenopathy. Lungs are clear to auscultation. What is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?
A. Epstein-Barr virus
B. Rhinovirus
C. Allergic rhinitis
D. Mycoplasma pneumonia
simulatable.sim_qa_expl: We know from the starter QA that headache is often caused by Rhinovirus, and because the patient in the follow-up question also has headache and cold symptomes, she likely also has Rhinovirus. The starter QA also states that no palpable cervical adenopathy indicates no Epstein-Barr virus and that clear lungs to auscultation suggests it's not Mycoplasma pneumonia. Because the patient in the follow-up question has clear lungs and no palpable cervical adenopathy, she likely does not have Epstein-Barr virus or Mycoplasma pneumonia. So the answer is B.
simulatable.relevant_qa_expl: Headache is often caused by Rhinovirus. No palpable cervical adenopathy indicates no Epstein-Barr virus. Clear lungs to auscultation suggests it's not Mycoplasma pneumonia. So the answer is B.

simulatable.orig_qn:
A previously healthy 32-year-old woman comes to the physician 8 months after her husband was killed in a car crash. Since that time, she has had a decreased appetite and difficulty falling asleep. She states that she is often sad and cries frequently. She has been rechecking the door lock five times before leaving her house and has to count exactly five pieces of toilet paper before she uses it. She says that she has always been a perfectionist but these urges and rituals are new. Pharmacotherapy should be targeted to which of the following neurotransmitters?
A. Dopamine
B. Serotonin
C. Norepinephrine
D. Glutamate
simulatable.orig_qa_tm_expl: The patient feels sad and among the options, only Dopamine and Serotonin can help increase positive emotions. Serotonin also affects digestion and metabolism, which can help the patient's decreased appetite and sleep difficulty.
simulatable.sim_qn:
A 60-year-old man presents with episodes of uncontrollable shaking, muscle stiffness, and difficulty with balance and coordination. Upon further questioning, the patient reports feeling apathetic, lacking motivation, and experiencing feelings of sadness. He also mentions having trouble falling asleep and has lost his appetite. Which neurotransmitter would be the most appropriate target for pharmacotherapy in this patient?
A. Dopamine
B. Norepinephrine
C. Serotonin
D. Glutamate
simulatable.sim_qa_expl: We know from the starter QA that Dopamine and Serotonin can help increase positive emotions, and that Serotonin can help the patient's decreased appetite and sleep difficulty. Because the patient in the follow-up question experiences sadness, has trouble falling asleep and loses his appetite, Serotonin is a good option for him. So the answer is C.
simulatable.relevant_qa_expl: Dopamine and Serotonin can help increase positive emotions. Serotonin can help the patient's decreased appetite and sleep difficulty. So the answer is C.

simulatable.orig_qn:
A 42-year-old man comes to the office for preoperative evaluation prior to undergoing adrenalectomy scheduled in 2 weeks. One month ago, he received care in the emergency department for pain over his right flank following a motor vehicle collision. At that time, blood pressure was 160/100 mm Hg and CT scan of the abdomen showed an incidental 10-cm left adrenal mass. Results of laboratory studies, including complete blood count, serum electrolyte concentrations, and liver function tests, were within the reference ranges. The patient otherwise had been healthy and had never been told that he had elevated blood pressure. He takes no medications. A follow-up visit in the office 2 weeks ago disclosed elevated urinary normetanephrine and metanephrine and plasma aldosterone concentrations. The patient was referred to a surgeon, who recommended the adrenalectomy. Today, vital signs are temperature 36.6째C (97.9째F), pulse 100/min, respirations 14/min, and blood pressure 170/95 mm Hg. Physical examination discloses no significant findings. Initial preoperative preparation should include treatment with which of the following?
A. Labetalol
B. A loading dose of potassium chloride
C. Nifedipine
D. Phenoxybenzamine
simulatable.orig_qa_tm_expl: The adrenal mass suggested pheochromocytoma, and the blood pressure indicates hypertension. Phenoxybenzamine is used to treat hypertension caused by pheochromocytoma.
simulatable.sim_qn:
A 38-year-old woman is scheduled for a surgery to remove a 9-cm right adrenal mass found incidentally on a CT scan after a car accident. She has been experiencing intermittent episodes of headaches, palpitations, and profuse sweating. Laboratory results show elevated urinary metanephrines and normetanephrines and high aldosterone levels. Her current blood pressure is 175/98 mm Hg. What would be the appropriate preoperative treatment to manage this patient's hypertension?
A. Bisoprolol
B. Phenoxybenzamine
C. Lisinopril
D. Hydrochlorothiazide
simulatable.sim_qa_expl: We know from the starter QA that adrenal mass suggests pheochromocytoma, and high blood pressure indicates hypertension. Because the patient in the follow-up question has adrenal mass and high pressure, she likely also has hypertension caused by pheochromocytoma. We know from the starter QA that Phenoxybenzamine is used to treat hypertension caused by pheochromocytoma, so the patient in the follow-up question also needs Phenoxybenzamine. So the answer is B.
simulatable.relevant_qa_expl: Adrenal mass suggests pheochromocytoma, and high blood pressure indicates hypertension. Phenoxybenzamine is used to treat hypertension caused by pheochromocytoma. So the answer is B.

unsimulatable.orig_qn:
Two days after undergoing emergency cardiac catherization for myocardial infarction, a 68-year-old woman has pain in her toes. During the intervention, she was found to have an occluded left anterior descending artery and 3 stents were placed. She has hypertension, hypercholesterolemia, and coronary artery disease. Prior to admission, her medications were metoprolol, enalapril, atorvastatin, and aspirin. Her temperature is 37.3°C (99.1°F), pulse is 93/min, and blood pressure is 115/78 mm Hg. Examination shows discoloration of the toes of both feet. A photograph of the right foot is shown. The lesions are cool and tender to palpation. The rest of the skin on the feet is warm; femoral and pedal pulses are palpable bilaterally. This patient is at increased risk for which of the following conditions?
A. Acute kidney injury
B. Basophilia
C. Permanent flexion contracture
D. Migratory thrombophlebitis
unsimulatable.orig_qa_tm_expl: The patient has discoloration of the toes, which could be due to emboli from the cardiac catheterization. This can lead to ischemia and increase the risk of acute kidney injury.

Pregnancy and delivery were uncomplicated but a prenatal ultrasound at 20 weeks showed a defect in the pleuroperitoneal membrane. A. Gastric fundus in the thorax
B. Pancreatic ring around the duodenum
C. Hypertrophy of the gastric pylorus
D. Large bowel in the inguinal canal
unsimulatable.sim_qa_expl: The starter QA does not directly help answer this question. So the answer is unknown.
